{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3558280,"name":"Devin Lee","username":"codeduck101","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/codeduck101/{size}/253970_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T14:16:33.727Z","cooked":"

As the title says. Briefly, after switching from MotionMagicVelocity MotionMagicVoltage requests to MotionMagicExpoVelocity MotionMagicExpoVoltage requests and a bit of PID tuning help from 1678 and 254, our elevator performed extremely well (as expected from the request’s reference).

However, afterwards, it started to be noticably slower than before on the way up and at a completely linear speed on the way down. This resembled an earlier problem we had while using MotionMagicVelocity MotionMagicVoltage requests and was briefly fixed when we switched to MotionMagicExpoVelocity MotionMagicExpoVoltage and retuned the elevator.
This is most prevalent when running from the maximum height to minimum height.
Allegedly, this new occurrence of this issue appeared after we had issues on the RIO CANbus, which the elevator’s motors are on.
We are running the elevator with two motors. The right motor is a follower of the left motor.
Here are some graphs of some measurements from CTRE’s hoot logs when running the elevator from max height to minimum height to better understand:

Properly functional

healthy_cycle_21612×1034 98.6 KB

Current behavior

suspicious_CADA_hoot_log_3-15_17-28-161612×1031 98.4 KB

I note that the measured stator current is significantly higher now than when it functioned. I don’t know exactly what stator current represents here, though, since it doesn’t seem to match up with the stator current limit on those motors of 80A, and the second motor has negative current when it functioned.

Additionally, on testing, the elevator seems to go slower upwards and slightly faster downwards when decreasing MotionMagicExpo kA and when increasing the motor’s kP through Phoenix Tuner X.
Our elevator’s kG also went from about 0.45 to over 1.2 without movement.
We have made a few code changes between when it worked and when it didn’t, but none should have affected elevator movement, and deploying older code that was what we had at the time did not fix this issue.

Here’s a link to the branch we’re using: GitHub - TeamVortechs/3257-COMP-ROBOT-3257-2025-Reefscape at Pre-SacramentoComp-Branch

That’s all I have on this issue. Thanks for helping.

(EDIT: We use MotionMagicVoltage, not Velocity.)

How did you tune your elevator? What is the issue with your CANbus? What is your gearing and mass which you are carriying? Looks like stator current is really high and it can damage your motors. What is the battery voltage when going up and down? Also is your robot changed mechanically?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T15:16:05.994Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":41.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495778,"topic_slug":"motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent","display_username":"Emre ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64968,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent/495778/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3558342,"name":"Devin Lee","username":"codeduck101","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/codeduck101/{size}/253970_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T15:33:30.635Z","cooked":"

We noticed this the first time (before we changed control requests) once the elevator was rebuilt. Same motor configuration used. The alleged resurfacing of the issue was when the RIO CANbus connection came loose during a match, which has since been fixed. From when we had the elevator working properly, the elevator was tuned by

  1. zeroing out all feedfoward/back constants in Phoenix Tuner X and the Motion Magic velocity/acceleration/jerk restrictions, then
  2. finding the low/high range of kG that kept the elevator still, then
  3. using the average of the range as our kG before
  4. moving onto using the default kV value and using the MotionMagicExpoVoltage request through Phoenix Tuner X
    After this, the elevator worked extremely well already. We further increased kV by 0.02 (0.12 → 0.14) and added a small kP (0.35) arbitrarily.
    After again testing the efficacy of these values, we set these values into preferences.
    These numbers were kept the same when the elevator had this issue again.
    While moving the elevator (not moving the robot), the battery starts at 12 volts and linearly decreases from 11.6 to 11.25 on ascent and is about a constant 11.35 on descent (see graph; bold yellow line represents voltage with scale on left; elevator height represented by thin purple line)
    image1611×1032 110 KB

I do not know the gearing and mass of the elevator.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T15:40:10.448Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":105,"readers_count":104,"score":31.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495778,"topic_slug":"motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent","display_username":"Devin Lee","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":64968,"username":"DukeEmree","name":"Emre ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dukeemree/{size}/251833_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74145,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3257 Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent/495778/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3558350,"name":"Emre ","username":"DukeEmree","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dukeemree/{size}/251833_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T15:44:24.355Z","cooked":"
codeduck101:

I do not know the gearing

If you are using kraken’s relative encoder it is important. If the gear ratio has changed, you need to set the pid and sensorToMechanism ratio again.
Also try to go up and down manually and see behaviour. If it doesn’t perform well enough, it could be a problem with the motor.

We use rotations as a measurement instead of meters. I’ll try VoltageOut control next.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T15:51:52.170Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":17.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495778,"topic_slug":"motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent","display_username":"Devin Lee","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":64968,"username":"DukeEmree","name":"Emre ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dukeemree/{size}/251833_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74145,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3257 Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent/495778/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3558522,"name":"Ryan Blue","username":"Ryan_Blue","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_blue/{size}/174016_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T19:20:48.070Z","cooked":"

The “current behavior” graph indicates both motors are being current limited both directions and isn’t able to keep up with the profile like it did before (though im not sure why motor 22 goes to 120a on the way down). Is there any chance the mechanism is encountering significant mechanical resistance now? Try moving it by hand with the robot off.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T19:21:40.716Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":79,"readers_count":78,"score":50.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495778,"topic_slug":"motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent","display_username":"Ryan Blue","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Dev | Redux Robotics| 1024 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent/495778/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3558549,"name":"Devin Lee","username":"codeduck101","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/codeduck101/{size}/253970_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T19:52:50.566Z","cooked":"

Turns out a bolt from the inner stage was touching the 2x1 of the outer stage. Seems like the PID might need more work, and I’m not sure if the descent is fixed yet. Will update when given answers.

What would cause motor that is configured as a follower, and set to stator max current 80; Why would one motor be higher stater current than the other and higher that max?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T20:00:33.283Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":24.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495778,"topic_slug":"motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent","display_username":"Mentor Matt Stemple","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":74145,"username":"codeduck101","name":"Devin Lee","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/codeduck101/{size}/253970_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20113,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor Matt 3257"},"post_url":"/t/motionmagicexpo-elevator-slowed-goes-at-linear-velocity-on-descent/495778/10","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3558563,"name":"Emre ","username":"DukeEmree","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dukeemree/{size}/251833_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T20:07:35.873Z","cooked":"

they should be close if they are under same load. Other motor need more power to follow because there is more resistance probably.

After setting up the follower, then applying the constructor to the follower motor same as the lead motor, will that break the follower setup? Because it wasn’t allow to inherit?

The follower setting occurs last in initialization. Additionally, the control mode is always Follower for the right motor.
I notice that the motor output status between each motor doesn’t match, but this happened much more often when the elevator functioned correctly, and it seems fine.

image1435×1028 161 KB

Here’s an update: We bumped up stator limits to 95A and explicitly set voltage limits of ±12 volts. It didn’t fix the underlying issue, but we are getting more voltage out of our motors.

image1708×1030 107 KB

(Half-hour later) It seems like the follower motor still follows the trend of measuring about double the stator limit.

image3075×2030 373 KB

Seems like this was satisfactory enough. Not sure if the high current will pose a danger to the motors over time, but it seems that a bit of PID tuning will have the elevator working fine? Thanks for helping out.
